item.title: About Us
item.dc:creator: mzier
item.content:encoded:
The Muse Collaborative is a young organization whose heart is intimately bound to the city and people that birthed it: Camden, NJ. Our grand vision is to see a Camden revered for its people, culture, and artistic merit and will pursue that end by promoting excellence in, expression through, and appreciation for the hip-hop arts (Breaking, Graffiti, DJing, and MCing). We intend to become a prominent nurturer and advocate of cultural participation and creativity while attesting to the importance of relationships, diversity, and respect both within our community and across society. By leveraging the intimate bond performance and visual arts create with programs designed to affirm the worth and value of both individuals and hip-hop, we hope to strengthen our community’s connection to the deep tradition of activism, empowerment, and identity building set forth by arts like the blues, jazz, and the many cultural roots hip-hop was born out of.

Our Guiding Values

Community is the real and dirty stuff of interconnected relationships, whether intentional or incidental, where individuals establish connections and craft belonging. Creativity is born out of internalized freedom and begets both purpose and value.  Through necessity, we learn to live; through creativity, we become. Respect is an active choice that puts action to our inner values.  It paints our relationships with others and shapes the way we see ourselves. Diversity is more than difference, it's a celebration of that which isn't like you, your history, or your surroundings.

Recent News

[display-posts category="muse-update" include_content="true" posts_per_page="1"] More News

item.title: Transparency
item.dc:creator: cmdmuse
item.content:encoded:
The Muse Collaborative is fully committed to open and transparent action in pursuit of its mission.  Because we're very much a community organization, we want our work, the reasons for it, and the goals we're aiming for to be known and shaped by our neighbors.  If you ever find something that concerns you in our documents or you have an idea for how we could be doing something better, please contact us and let us know. All documents we share are available for public use in accordance with Creative Commons Non-Commercial, Share Alike licensing.  The art of the remix is fundamental to hip-hop, so our work is open for others to use (as long as you share it in-kind).  Additionally, source code for digital assets we create is available under the GNU General Public License v3.0 on our GitHub repository . Public documents such as our 501(c)(3) determination letter are available upon request (info@themusecollaborative.org)

Annual Report

2016 - Forthcoming

Finance

2017 - Filed an IRS 990-N (electronic postcard); no compensation paid to staff 2016 - Filed an IRS 990-N (electronic postcard); no compensation paid to staff 2015 - Filed an IRS 990-N (electronic postcard); no compensation paid to staff

organizational Documents

item.title: Employment
item.dc:creator: cmdmuse

item.title: Get Involved
item.dc:creator: cmdmuse
item.content:encoded:
As an organization defined by its relationships, The Muse Collaborative is constantly looking to connect people into its network.  Whether you want to follow one of our predefined paths or carve out your own, please get a hold of us and let us know.

Chat with a staff member

No matter how info@themusecollaborative.org.

Community ROUNDTABLE

Once every two weeks, The Muse Collaborative holds an open dialogue about its programs and plans, the needs of the community, and any other topic of interest residents choose to voice.  Find out more here.

Volunteer Opportunities

We are currently looking for both generalist volunteers and those with specific, professional skill sets (e.g. financial auditing, social media marketing, etc.).  Volunteers are asked to commit to a set amount of time every week for their service and work with the organization for at least two months.  Please fill out our Volunteer Form and we'll get back to you as soon as possible.

item.title: HEAR/SPEAK
item.dc:creator: cmdmuse
item.content:encoded: Adaptable to a wide variety of public venues, HEAR/SPEAK is an eight-week listening series designed to help individuals and communities appreciate and celebrate the richness of hip-hop history while simultaneously exploring pressing social issues.  The format and feel of every event is tailored to its hosting venue and each series is crafted by local research assistants. If you're interested in having The Muse Collaborative facilitate HEAR/SPEAK at your organization (e.g. bar, business training, church, library, school, youth program, or other social venue) or if you'd like to help fund the development of a new listening series, please contact us at info@themusecollaborative.org.   TITLE Brief story about album sets. Pellentesque purus libero, porta vitae molestie vel, commodo nec massa. item.title: Mission / Vision
item.dc:creator: mzier
item.content:encoded:
Our Vision

A Camden revered for its people, culture, and artistic merit and will pursue

Our Mission

To promote excellence in, expression through, and appreciation for the hip-hop arts

Our Guiding Values

Community is the real and dirty stuff of interconnected relationships, whether intentional or incidental, where individuals establish connections and craft belonging. Creativity is born out of internalized freedom and begets both purpose and value.  Through necessity, we learn to live; through creativity, we become. Respect is an active choice that puts action to our inner values.  It paints our relationships with others and shapes the way we see ourselves. Diversity is more than difference, it's a celebration of that which isn't like you, your history, or your surroundings.

item.title: Artist Resources
item.dc:creator: mzier
item.content:encoded: Grants Leeway Foundation - funding women and trans artists Art and Change Grant - The Art and Change Grant is a project-based grant that provides up to $2,500 to fund art for social change projects.  The grant is distributed two times per year Leeway Transformation Award - The $15,000 grant honors artists who have demonstrated a commitment to creating art for social change for five years or more.  This award is distributed once per year and involves a two-stage selection process More information at: http://www.leeway.org/ Graffiti legal walls – location, details (ask graffiti crews if advertisement of space is harmful to their art)

item.title: MUSE Update #1
item.dc:creator: mzier
item.content:encoded: While all of us here at The Muse Collaborative have been working away behind the scenes for a while, we wanted to start reaching out to the world and this site is one of our first steps.  We’ll be rolling out a lot of new content over the summer connected to our initial programs (and a website that looks like it wasn’t designed in 2002) , but until that time posts might be few and far between.  In the meantime, feel free to add us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.  While we’re keeping a low profile until the real excitement starts, subscribing early means you’ll get all of our updates once they go public. From Camden, ~ michael

item.title: Calendar
item.dc:creator: cmdmuse

item.title: Now Open: Research Assistant Positions
item.dc:creator: mzier
item.content:encoded:
Download Position Announcement The Muse Collaborative is looking for three research assistants to work in a team-based environment and create/curate content for its first community program.  The researcher team will be tasked with studying and developing materials for 8 hip-hop albums, including but not limited to: accurate lyric sheets, links for sampled songs, original articles and publications for each album, and interviews to support such articles.  While each member of the team isn't expected to be proficient in every skill mentioned below, the group as a whole will have expertise in:
  • Research or journalism
  • Hip-hop history
  • Camden history and culture
Each researcher will be provided with office supplies, program training, and training materials, and will be compensated at $10/hr (for a maximum of 80 hours).  Due to limited capacity, The Muse Collaborative cannot provide access to workstations at this time.  While each member of the team is expected to contribute eighty hours of work to the project, additional volunteer effort is welcomed. Researchers are strongly encouraged to attend the events resulting from their work and are also welcome to join us in raising funds for further cycles of the program.  While additional financial compensation cannot be offered for fundraising efforts at this time, support and training will be provided for any member of the team interested in nonprofit development. Requirements
  • Able to commit ~15 hours per week until completion to the project
  • Able to meet with all team members once a week in Camden during the project
  • Passion for hip-hop arts and culture
  • Legally eligible to work in the United States (felonies are not a disqualifier)
  • Strong preference is given to residents of Camden city
Applicants should send a resume and a brief description of themselves and their interest in the position to michael@themusecollaborative.org.  If submitting a digital application poses difficulty for you, please call (856) 209-0730 to arrange an alternative application plan. All applications are due by September 29th, 2017 at 5:00 pm. The Muse Collaborative does not discriminate on the basis of race, creed, ancestry, marital status, gender, sexual orientation, age, physical disability, veteran’s status, political service or affiliation, color, religion, economic status, or national origin.

item.title: MUSE Update #2
item.dc:creator: mzier
item.content:encoded: We've been pretty quiet as per usual, working away behind the scenes on all the little details most people aren't interested in.  The good news?  We're gearing up to launch programming in 2017, meaning all our preparation, all the behind-the-scenes details like computer coding, document design, strategy meetings, and coffee drinking will finally pay off.  As always, we'd rather talk with you than have you read a post, so if you're interested in where things are, please don't hesitate to get in touch. From Camden, ~ michael

item.title: Chris Williams
item.dc:creator: cmdmuse
item.content:encoded: My name is Christopher Williams. I like to go by Knehmo. Its a spin on nemo, a Latin word that translates to something like, "no-one" or "no-man," and I get a kick introducing myself to people as nobody. I like long walks to thrift stores, appreciate Hennessy, and plan to make a more deliberate effort to show the people I care about that I care about them. But enough about me, onto the music. Oldheads mention the greats: Jay-Z, Rakim, Nas, Big Pun, Big Daddy Kane, NWA, Biggie, and the like. Since I was born in ‘94, all these artists feel like they're from the stone ages of rap. <Some transition to a list of personal embrace of hiphop> The summers I remember in Camden were thick with the sounds of Reggaeton, Lil John, and the Eastside Boys. I found and fell for Jersey Club and Chopped and Screwed Music remixes early in my twenties. Dj Noir’s remix of No Feelings by PARTYNEXTDOOR and Travis Scott got me through hard times. If you can really hear DJ Blazee B’s mix of Trey Songz' Still Scratching Me Up and not dance, you're probably the FEDs. Hip-hop has been a big part of my life and I look forward to digging through songs I would have had on my playlists either way. ARTICLES: [display-posts author="cwilliams"]

item.title: Black Brilliance and Recognition: Hip-hop, Hurray!
item.dc:creator: cwilliams
item.content:encoded:
“Misery is often the parent of the most affecting touches in poetry. —Among the blacks is misery enough, God knows, but no poetry. Love is the peculiar œstrum of the poet. Their love is ardent, but it kindles the senses only, not the imagination. Religion indeed has produced a Phyllis Whately [sic]; but it could not produce a poet. The compositions published under her name are below the dignity of criticism.”

– Thomas Jefferson, Notes on the State of Virginia

“…And yet, this is precisely what Gordon argues is the value and insight of Fanon: he fully accepts the definition of himself as pathological as it is imposed by a world that knows itself through that imposition, rather than remaining in a reactive stance that insists on the (temporal, moral, etc.) heterogeneity between a self and an imago originating in culture. Though it may appear counterintuitive, or rather because it is counterintuitive, this acceptance or affirmation is active; it is a willing or willingness, in other words, to pay whatever social costs accrue to being black, to inhabiting blackness, to living a black social life under the shadow of social death. This is not an accommodation to the dictates of the antiblack world. The affirmation of blackness, which is to say an affirmation of pathological being, is a refusal to distance oneself from blackness in a valorization of minor differences that bring one closer to health, to life, or to sociality."

– Jared Sexton, The Social Life of Social Death: On Afropessimism and Black Optimism

  Is Jefferson's critique of Phyllis Wheatley really that far off from criticisms of Future? It is relatively recent that the drug addled, aggressive mess consumed by morally and fiscally bankrupt blacks known as Hip-Hop is acknowledged as an actual music category in the public imaginary. Is it possible to support the "best" of rap and the "worst" in the same breath without falling into the trap of respectability rhetoric? What purpose does the continuum of rap worthy of praise and the stuff below artistic merit serve? I'm going to call it. 2pac will go down as one of the rap greats because he was a trained ballerina. He would have been accustomed to deliberate walking on tiptoe. Did he see the tightropes? I mean, we all know the balancing act, right? Do you make music too black to be music, or make music too formulaic to be honest? Realness or Recognition? Radio play or your soul? Faced with those options, the best decision could be to deliberately drop from the rope. Its like untying a knot by cutting it, to shatter a continuum by over identifying with one of the poles. I think that the thug life tattooed across 2Pac's stomach is the realization of Jefferson's criticism of Wheatley's work and, at the same time, a bold statement that bucks Jefferson's authority as critic. To painstakingly argue for Rap's legitimacy as an art form by comparing it to the time signatures of Orchestral pieces or pointing to how easily it meshes with Rock, Country and other genres is to miss the point completely. 2Pac's response was this: Sure, this might not be art, but fuck you. You never had enough clout for your opinion to matter anyway. Its as if only God could judge him. I'd like to turn to a brilliant artwork with this in mind, Bone Thugs and Harmony's Thuggish Ruggish Bone. The song is a brilliant response to the voice of reason. The introduction is lifted from a 1993 sermon by Calvin O. Butts on gangster rap. He draws a clear line between the good blacks and those bad ones who make a bad name for the law abiding folks. What a convenient response, these musicians are responsible for the general associations of race and criminality, not the ongoing drug war, not housing practices and nothing structural: pure individual choice. When blacks are already criminal in the political imaginary, a defense of their work can be enough to be labeled as an accessory. Bone's rebuttal is an argument by bypassing the very terms of engagement. There is no calculated move toward convincing Butts to change his opinion and become not against those thugs. They never try to prove Ice T or Easy E benefitted their communities. Instead, the song is a bold endorsement and praise of rap, rappers and those thugs who produce it, an embrace of pathology without pathos. Bipartisan reasoning for the right to be was not their style. This song is a polemic. And rightly so. What are the stakes of this music? These aren't just songs to nod your head to. These are fragments of life compressed into 3 minute tracks. Hip Hop is the disorder of black creativity, the aftermath of slavery and all its debris, ring shouts turned cyphers, plantation wailings and conspiratorial thoughts backed by murderous rhythm. Hand claps, chained artists jazzy at the auction block. To defend one’s heritage here is also to ask, what does it mean to say fuck policing, musically? Not fuck the police, that is a conversation for a different time. But policing, that subtle force that makes you wary of enjoying yourself too loudly for fear of criticism. What if they heard you enjoying that...trash? You wouldn't want them to think you listen to that music...although you do. This is an invitation to refusal as an ethics. Refuse being deputized against yourself; there are enough external neighborhood watchmen quick to condemn rap for us or kill black teenagers for “being tired of being told what to do” too loudly in their cars. The party goers who live for the weekends they can blast XO Tour Llif3 with their friends and mourn the decline of lyricism on Monday. The selective badge flashers who quickly let Nas, Wu-Tang, and the other real rappers through but are quick to frisk Desiigner and 21 Savage because they fit the description: young, black, aggressive, and wanted for the murder of real rap. And to the critics, this is in the spirit of Martin Luther King. Not the white washed ghost summoned to quell black dissatisfaction with white supremacy and systemic inequality, that kitschy Martin whose memorial in D.C. is an all lives matter display etched in stone. This is the hurt, disenchanted, jeremiadic post-Vietnam Martin blasting Public Enemy and SZA that when asked about rioters, hesitantly responded that a riot is the language of the unheard. The Martin who lost hope for himself and was ready to die. And now, the thing I was waiting to do from the beginning. <GIF> This is for my niggas. The tired. The shook ones. The ones who make time to create after the 9 to 5. The risk takers who had police called on them when they were just trying to make enough money to feed their daughters. My niggas. All the greats mentioned and forgotten: Big Pun, Kendrick, Young Thug, Run DMC, Rapsody, SoundCloud rappers, audience members who know the lyrics better than the artists, the dead homies, real ones behind bars who will die before betraying their friends, illegal immigrants, Pastors, that one guy in office before dude with the freshly husked corn toupee. Mom Dukes. In short, my niggas. My niggas who feel like 16 bars can be a prison but speak freely regardless. We feel you, and we know. Fuck their judgement, we will make our own seats at the table if we have to. We already have. We owe no explanations. We will dwell in our secrets. Let them have the scraps they steal as they ridicule us. We'll just create and dance in ways they 'appreciate' abstractly because they can’t do it themselves. Most critics would get laughed out of a cypher anyway. Why leave deciphering value to them? It was never theirs to begin with. This shit is for us. And a last word to Jefferson. It was never Wheatley. You’re the Nigger, baby. Ol’ slave havin’ ass. Knehmo

item.title: Aaron Cooper
item.dc:creator: cmdmuse
item.content:encoded: What’s up world? My name is Aaron Cooper and I’m an eclectic mix between a classic renaissance man and the 80’s and 90’s true-school hustler. Not in the street hustler sense but rather if there’s a goal or something I deem obtainable, I’m going to do whatever’s needed to get it and work as hard as I can to get things done within. More often than not, the goal and end results mean more to me than the time it takes to get there. As a graphic artist, DJ, photographer, mentor and spoken-word artist who’s been around since the early days of hip-hop (remember when MTV actually showed music videos and BET only came on at certain times?), I see music as something reveals social dynamics and teaches us about the world. My musical tastes differ from many of the “young old heads” – I can be caught dissecting The Temptations and the whole Motown / Staxx era, listening to Bing Crosby and Esperanza Spaulding, rocking out to classic rap and R&B, getting caught up in Kirk Franklin or 80’s and 90’s Golden Era hip-hop, all while still respecting and finding common ground with today’s Kodak Blacks and Kendrick Lamars. I enjoy listening to other peoples’ playlists and find lots of new connections can be discovered when you open up and explore what’s on someone’s phone, iPod, or CD deck. ARTICLES: [display-posts author="acooper"]

item.title: Damilola Adedeji
item.dc:creator: cmdmuse
item.content:encoded: My name is Damilola Adedeji and I am from Africa – that’s a continent, not a country by the way. I grew in Nigeria and spent the most of my life there. I prefer to be called by my first name and like anything outdoors, especially soccer. And then there’s music. I love music: African music, EDM, pretty much anything. I’ll give everything a chance… except for Metal, don’t have any patience for it. Music influences me—it inspires me. Multiple people, including some of my friends, have told me they don’t really listen to music and every time I hear that I can’t imagine how much of a void must be in their lives. Since the dawn of time, music has been more than an art form. It’s a way of of life and an escape during tough times. Music can define, inspire, separate, and bring people together. Nietzsche said it best: “Without music, life would be a mistake.” ARTICLES: [display-posts author="dadedeji"]

item.title: Damilola Reviews: Like Father, Like Son
item.dc:creator: dadedeji
item.content:encoded:
Like Father, Like Son is a collaborative studio album by American rappers Birdman and Lil Wayne. The album was released on October 31, 2006, through Cash Money Records and Universal Records. To me it is consider a classic and frankly speaking i could care less if an album goes platinum or not. But to me, this album is good while generally speaking not the best as there are some albums out right now or in the past that i might choose from. but nonetheless, i like it because if features some reputable stars like tpain, fatjoe, snoop dogg and so forth. the album start of with a track called 'loyalty'. which means family, respect, and frankly not taking bullshit and not giving one either, well except they deserve it.
The first single album which was titled "stuntin like my daddy" it has rhythm and style but the constant repetition of the word daddy really stands out lol. back in 2006, i guess the term daddy was accepted but to a kid listening to that music in today's world will be withdrawn completely. i personally like' 1ST CRACK' because it resonate with everybody that ever live that lifestyle, u know the first time is always scary. And it also cater to people who are really about that life. lil wayne earned my respect with his music from this era. frankly speaking, i am overwhelmed by the controversy surrounding these artist. there are people who love wayne of back in the day and there are people who don't support his work now. at the end of the day, artist get money, they get lazy when they get that grammy. it's all about the money. The album is very repetitive and almost every track is basically the same with just a different beat. Its always about money no matter what. But nonetheless am a fan of Cash Money and this is must buy. My Favorite Tracks are "Stuntin' Like My Daddy", "1ST CRACK", "Leather So Soft".

item.title: Damilola Review: Good Kid, M.A.A.D City
item.dc:creator: dadedeji
item.content:encoded:
The singles released from this project were good but not great. Once the album was released, I realized how great those singles were. This album must be consumed as a whole.
As with Section.80, Kendrick is storytelling with each track. This album surpasses Section.80 in cohesion, production, and imagery. The cover art says "a short film" and that's exactly what this album feels like. You're listening but it feels like you're watching this young man grow up in Compton. You understand his external and internal struggles. Even a track like Backseat Freestyle makes perfect sense for anyone who's spent time in a car with their friends freestyling to waste time and talk about girls.
It is amazingly ambitious for a young artist to risk using his first album to tell a story. The temptation to put the 'hottest' mc's on the project was avoided (except for Drake on Poetic Justice, which seems like a 3rd party in a two-way conversation). This album is focused and that focus pays off for the listener as the story comes full circle by the end.
The music industry has been scrambling ever since sites like Napster showed that the days of producing albums with 3-4 good songs and 5-8 songs of filler are over. Kendrick seems to offer a solution with this album. "Don't make songs. Make albums".

item.title: Vedra Chandler
item.dc:creator: cmdmuse
item.content:encoded: Vedra Chandler is a singer in pursuit of social justice from Camden, New Jersey. After receiving a degree in Government from Harvard University, Vedra worked briefly in the fascinating sphere of supply chain logistics before following her heart to a career in music. She belted and shimmied her way through several national tours and regional theater productions of popular Broadway musicals before officially running away with the circus in 2010 when she accepted the role of “Soul Singer” in Cirque Du Soleil’s Kooza. “I have been so fortunate to travel the world spreading art, music and joy, but to me, there is no place like home.” In 2015 Vedra returned to her hometown where she spends her days managing Connect the Lots Camden, a creative place-making initiative at Cooper’s Ferry Partnership. She strives to support our local arts community and create a true sense of place for residents of this vibrant city. When she’s not planning a pop-up park or city-wide music festival, Vedra can be found practicing yoga, enjoying Pino Grigio, playing Settlers of Catan, watching South Park, or performing with her musical trio CPR: Music Invincible on 3rd Thursdays at the Victor Lofts.

item.title: Peggy Jean Craig
item.dc:creator: cmdmuse
item.content:encoded: PJ is committed to The Muse Collaborative because of what the arts have done for her and the people she loves. Throughout her life, she’s continually coming back to music, dance, and art to find beauty, express herself, and connect to others. She may or may not also have all the choreography for Aaliyah's Are You That Somebody memorized in ready-to-perform shape. After giving up her childhood dream of being a pop star, and then a folk singer, PJ decided to try her hand at something equally challenging and rewarding – youth development. Today, she spends her time hanging out with 4th -12th graders and college students who are smarter, cooler, and funnier than her. As the Assistant Director of K12 Partnerships at Rutgers University–Camden, PJ oversees programs like Rutgers Future Scholars and the Ignite after-school program. Before Rutgers, PJ was Executive Director of The Advocate Center for Culture and Education in North Philadelphia, an organization that focuses on youth identity and success rooted in the tradition of social justice and Black Power. She is currently working on her PhD in Community Development/Public Affairs at Rutgers, and holds an MS in Public Affairs and an MDiv with a concentration in church and community leadership as well. When she's not working on choreography to Keith Sweat songs, PJ cooks, eats, and instagrams what she eats with her husband, Matt, and their Havanese dog, Pepper.

item.title: Joe White
item.dc:creator: cmdmuse
item.content:encoded: "Hip-hop for me, it's my story. Early DMX, KRS-One's Return of the Boom Bap, Gang Starr, Jay Z on Reasonable Doubt – those guys are the soundtrack of my life. They rap about the struggle and trying to be successful, about the normal, every day up and down." Born and raised in Camden, Joseph White is a dedicated father and husband, a screen printer, and music lover. He was one of the first supporters of The Muse Collaborative and joined the board to help others in his city chase dreams he wasn't able to dream. Joe has worked for Camden Printworks for over fifteen years, helped found BIGNOIZEINC, coaches a local football team, and is a strong supporter of Rising Leaders, UrbanPromise, and Project HOPE. He grew up playing trombone, trumpet, and percussion and was part of Woodrow Wilson's marching band all throughout high school. "Really, I want to give back. I'm always trying to figure out how to connect people in their situation to other people moving in the same direction, even if that's just getting someone's local business on a t-shirt."

item.title: Michael Zier
item.dc:creator: cmdmuse
item.content:encoded: Michael Zier - michael@themusecollaborative.org Executive Director Michael is a Camden resident with family roots in the Midwest and an extensive resume in community organizing, grassroots development, and philosophy, including work with The American Red Cross, The Center for Environmental Transformation, AmeriCorps VISTA, PeaceCorps, and UrbanPromise.  He's a musician at heart who loves Russian and French literature, learning from others' lived experiences, and cooking for friends.  He is also a painfully incompetent dancer.
